assessment.title: Online Lecture - Week 1 - UNIT II (2 of 2)

material.mattext:
Online Lecture Activity Instructions

  • This is a self-paced activity.

  • There is no time limit.

  • You may repeat the lecture and questions as many times as needed.

  • Take notes as you go to help with understanding.

  • Complete the comprehension questions as you go through the lecture.

Lesson for Unit II: Summarizing Data

Activities in this Lesson:

  • OpenIntro Video 2.1 - Summarizing and Graphing Numerical Data
  • StatsQuest Video 1 - Histograms
  • Reading Section: Brief Intro to Probabilities
  • StatsQuest Video 2 and 3 - The Population, Probability Distribution, Estimators and Population Parameters
  • StatsQuest Video 4 - Calculating the Mean, Variance, and Standard Deviation
  • OpenIntro Video 2.2 - Considering Categorical Data

section.title: Section 1 - Summarizing and Graphing Numerical Data

material.mattext:
Summarizing and Graphing Numerical Data

OpenIntro Video 2.1

Please carefully watch this section's video.
True or False: “The video mentions that a dot plot is essentially a one-variable scatterplot.”
True
False

More on Histograms

StatsQuest Video 1 - Histograms

Please carefully watch this section's video.
True or False: “The video claims that if the histogram bins are too narrow, almost every measurement ends up in its own bin.”
True
False

(S2-Q1) Summarizing and Graphing Numerical Data

Assume a given state has a total population (in thousands) distributed across different age cohorts as follows:

Age Cohort (Years) Population (in thousands) Cumulative Count (in thousands)
0-10 800 800
11-20 700 1500
21-30 600 2100
31-40 500 2600
41-50 400 3000
51-60 300 3300
61+ 200 3500

True or False: "According to the table, the cumulative population count surpasses 2,900 thousand at the 41-50 age cohort"
True
False

(S2-Q2) Summarizing and Graphing Numerical Data

To compute probabilities from a cumulative count table, divide each cohort’s count by the overall total, and do the same with cumulative counts for “up to” probabilities:

  • Probability of a specific cohort: P(21 to 30) = 600 / 3500 ≈ 0.171 (i.e. cohort size ÷ total population).
  • Cumulative probability “up to” a cohort: P(age ≤ 30) = 2100 / 3500 = 0.600 (i.e. cumulative count ÷ total).
  • General formulas:
    • P(\[a to b\]) = Population_{[a to b]} ÷ Total
    • P(age ≤ b) = CumulativeCount_{[0 to b]} ÷ Total

Question: Considering the previous table, select all the correct answers.

(S2-Q3) Summarizing and Graphing Numerical Data

Understanding a distribution’s shape—and its skewness—is crucial because it guides how we summarize data and anticipate unusual values:

  • Symmetric distributions (skew ≈ 0) look like mirror images on both sides; mean and median coincide, so the “average” truly represents a typical observation.
  • Right-skewed distributions (positive skew) have a long tail to the right; a few large values pull the mean above the median, warning us that extremes can inflate the average.
  • Left-skewed distributions (negative skew) have a long tail to the left; a handful of low values drag the mean below the median, alerting us that outliers may understate central tendency.

Consider the following histogram, created with the data from the previous table.

Question: Which of the following correctly describes the shape of the distribution?

section.title: Section 3 - A Brief Intro to Basic Probabilities

material.mattext:
Reading Section: Brief Intro to Probabilities.

Definition of Probability

In this subsection, we'll briefly introduce the concept of probability from a frequentist perspective. We have previously explored probabilities in scenarios such as the Monty Hall Problem and in the context of the Presidential Election. Now, we will provide a more formal definition, setting the stage for a deeper exploration in Unit III of the syllabus.

From the frequentist viewpoint, probability measures how likely an event is to occur based on its frequency over a very large number of trials. For example, consider flipping a coin. A 'fair' coin is one where, if flipped a theoretically infinite number of times, you would expect it to land on heads about half of the time and on tails the other half. This idea leads us to expect that the probability of either outcome is one half.

Suppose one of your friends finds a coin on the street and wonders whether it is fair. How could you determine if the coin is likely fair or not?

(S3-b) Brief Intro to Probabilities.

The Coin Experiment.

Imagine you decide on conducting an experiment. You decide to flip the coin 20 times, recording each outcome and counting how many times it lands on heads.

When flipping a coin, only two outcomes are possible: heads or tails. If the coin has been tampered with (perhaps due to an odd shape or a non-uniform distribution of weight), these modifications might influence its landings.

The true underlying probability of the coin landing on heads would ideally be estimated by observing its landings over a very large number of flips. However, for practical purposes, we start with just 20 flips to gather initial data.

After flipping the coin 20 times, suppose it lands on heads 14 times.

True or False: "After 20 flips, the coin landed on heads fewer than half of the time."
True
False

(S3-c) Brief Intro to Probabilities.

Discussion.

Results of the Experiment: {Heads: 14 times, Tails: 6 times}. This preliminary result suggests a 70% frequency of heads (14/20 = 0.7).

However, before drawing conclusions, we should consider whether 20 flips are sufficient to determine if the coin is fair. Because of the inherent variability and randomness in the experiment, even if the coin is truly a fair coin, short experiments can yield misleading results. Thus, to explore further, you might decide to increase the number of flips to 100 or even 1000 to see if the frequency of heads approaches 50%, which would strengthen the argument for the coin's fairness.

Key Takeaways

Trial: In the most abstract sense, a 'trial' refers to a specific instance of observing or measuring an event, process, or activity.

Frequentist Probability: This approach defines the probability of an outcome as its relative frequency over numerous trials.

Experiment Size and Bias: In experiments with a small number of trials, like our 20 coin flips, the estimated probability can significantly differ from the true probability. This difference highlights the importance of large sample sizes in obtaining more accurate probability estimates. But note that it is also important that our experiment is not biased, ensuring that each trial is a true random draw and represents the underlying phenomenon accurately.

Question:

True or False: "Under the frequentist definition of probability, the chance of heads is the long-run relative frequency—so a small experiment of just 20 flips can yield a misleading 70% heads, whereas increasing to 100 or 1000 flips should make the observed head frequency converge toward the true 50% value for a fair coin."
True
False

section.title: Section 4 - The Population, Probability Distribution, Estimators and Population Parameters

material.mattext:
Probability Distributions, Population and Estimated Parameters

StatsQuest Videos 2 and 3

Please carefully watch the following video.
True or False: “The speaker mentions that both histograms and the curves that approximate them are considered distributions because they show how probabilities are spread out.”
True
False

(S4-b) Probability Distributions, Population and Estimated Parameters

StatsQuest Video 3

Please carefully watch the following video.

True or False: If you draw a random sample from a population, the sample mean xˉ\bar{x} will always equal the population mean μ\mu.
True
False

(S4-Q1) Probability Distributions, Population and Estimated Parameters

Question: Which of the following studies is interested in measuring the dispersion of data, as we have studied in this lesson?

(S4-Q2) Probability Distributions, Population and Estimated Parameters

A politician is interested in gauging policy preferences in her district to better understand the opinions of her constituents. She wants to determine the overall support for a new healthcare policy. To do this, she conducts a survey of 1,000 randomly selected residents from her district. The survey results show that 60% of the respondents support the new policy.

section.title: Section 5 - Calculating the Mean, Variance, and Standard Deviation

material.mattext:
Calculating the Mean, Variance, and Standard Deviation

StatsQuest Video 4

Please carefully watch the following video.

(S5-Q1-a) Calculating the Mean, Variance, and Standard Deviation

Suppose the following is a data table containing observations of roll call votes for each member of a subcommittee in Congress.

Representative Total Votes Number of YEAS Number of NAYS Percentage of YEAS Votes
John Doe 74 69 5 93.24%
Jane Smith 77 19 58 24.68%
Emily Johnson 94 93 1 98.94%
Michael Brown 97 31 66 31.96%

Considering the information in the table, select all the correct answers:

(Hint: Compute the appropriate statistics before answering. You can consult the book or the slides too for formulas).

(S5-Q1-b) Considering the information in the table, select all the correct answers:
Submit Answers

Considering Categorical Data

OpenIntro Video 2.2

Please carefully watch the following video.
True or False: “In the video, it is mentioned that the contingency table for the email data set contains a total of 3,921 emails.”
True
False

(S6-Q1) Considering Categorical Data

Party Supports Policy A Supports Policy B Supports Policy C
Party X 30 40 50
Party Y 20 35 45

Short Reading:

For categorical nominal variables, the mean and median are not well defined statistics. Instead, for such variables we rely on the mode as a measure of central tendency. The mode of a categorical nominal variable is the most common category, the category with the highest frequency. 

Question: Given the table, considering both parties, what is the modal policy supported? (that is, the mode among the policies)
